February 22, 1963
Mr. William G. Harley
President, NAEB
1346 Connecticut Ave„,
Washington 6, D.C.
Dear Bill:
After receiving your personally typed letter which arrived here February
18th, I called together a small committee to review this signal example
of manual dexterity and linguistic skill. It was the committee^ unani¬
mous opinion that you should not only further pursue your exploration of
old English and ancient Vedic, but in view of your quick and remarkable
grasp of this area of scholarship that you also turn your attention to
Sanskrit and the irregular verbs in Beowulf as an imperative next step.
i agree with your suggestion that there is little point in proceeding with
a partial meeting of the Executive Committee in Chicago on the 16th and go
along with your suggestion that you, John S. and I meet in New York on the
afternoon of the 19th. We can meet informally with Miles at Chicago.
(Talked with him yesterday and he feels Sunday afternoon about 1:00 p.m.
is the time to do it—I agreed tentatively but am not completely sure I
can make it this early in the day. Will try, however, to do so). We
(you and l) will have to clear out of Chicago before the Region III meet¬
ing is over on the 19th probably around noon. When you return indicate
what time you, John, and I will meet and what time we meet with the
affi1iate group.
Later we can have a full dress meeting with Kager et al with more time and-
a more complete agenda.
The new governor and his cohorts are giving state agencies a continuing
series of traumatic experiences—a 9.1 budget cut, dismissal of 4000 em¬
ployees, etc. All of this has not helped my mental convalescence in this
post hospital period of seat cushions and non-phi1osophica1 contemplation.
However, I am progressing nicely, and my only real complaint is frustration
that my energy level did not automatically snap back to full speed ahead.
Sincerely
Richard B. Hul1
